pros: Great sense of community on campus
cons: Too much turnover in staff due to poor leadership

pros: Kind and engaging people, great location, community feel.
cons: Small with a sense of everyone knowing everything about you.

pros: It's a small college on an absolutely gorgeous campus on Sebago Lake in Maine. Staff are committed to the core values of the College. The Seven Core Values put in place by the Sisters of Mercy are respected and adheres to by the administration.
cons: The College missed the boat on distance education 15 years ago and played catch-up for years. High turnover in President and VP hiring caused a series of unrealistic goals for the College. Strategic plans changed very couple of years with very little accomplished. The majority of students are average achievers; SJC was often referred to as Grade 13 as there was a very high-school feel. Students are largely apathetic; there is very little activism, liberal or conservative, among students. What was once a college founded by the Sisters of Mercy, staffed by Sisters, it is now "college first, Catholic second."  This is the official marketing/public relations position and downright offensive to the women who built Saint Joseph's College. These women dedicated their lives to their faith and to education, and their legacy is now the stuff of legend on Campus, not practice.

pros: Overall a good attitude by very hard working staff
cons: At one time this school had a very good "On Line" program, it is now in total disarray, this could be a very high profit center but the administration seems to not have any idea how to run an "on line program".  They have gone to a traditional semester system which is not good for the average on line student, they have cut salaries and benefits for staff and no longer pay for items such as "first in" students, course design and development, student evaluations of instructors and course design.

pros: SJC is full of warm and engaged people. The HR team is solid, and well managed. The campus itself is amazing.
cons: Due to layoffs and strange decision making the senior leadership team is one of the biggest groups on campus. This is kind of strange for a small private school. Layoffs have been steady for the past several years, and the school is in a constant state of financial panic.

review_title: Currently in Transition but a good place to work
cons: Lack of good leadership up until a year ago has created a highly siloed culture.

too many to list, however to begin, the area coordinators never said one positive thing, never support RA's in decision making, always criticized and accused, worked against the RA's in many aspects, spoke condescendingly
